nodes.text: Changing how students are allocated to colleges can substantially reduce parental-income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational income mobility in the United States

Method: constructed near-complete administrative dataset linking federal tax records, Department of Education 1098-T and Pell records, College Board and ACT scores to measure college attended, parents' household incomes (averaged ages 15–19), students' earnings (age 32–34), and test scores
Claim: Parental income segregation across colleges is very large and comparable to parental income segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP codes)

Evidence: Ivy-Plus colleges have 14.5% of students from top 1% parents and only 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are 77 times more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than children from bottom quintile; community colleges show opposite pattern
Claim: Differences in postcollege earnings between children from low- and high-income families are much smaller within the same college than across colleges

Result/Evidence: National rank-rank slope of child on parent income is 0.288; controlling for college fixed effects reduces slope to ~0.10–0.14 (within-college slopes much smaller), implying much of persistence is between colleges

Claim: Colleges with the best average earnings outcomes predominantly enroll students from high-income families but some mid-tier public colleges combine high shares of low-income students with good earnings outcomes (high mobility rates)

Evidence/Result: Enrollment-weighted correlation between mean parent income rank and mean student earnings rank is ~0.78; examples of high mobility mid-tier publics include CUNY campuses, Cal State campuses, and SUNY Stony Brook; Ivy-Plus show especially high upper-tail mobility
Claim: Much of income segregation across colleges is not explained by geographic differences in local income pools; two-thirds of variation in bottom-quintile shares is within selectivity tiers

Method/Assumption: To simulate mobility effects, estimate colleges' mean earnings premia conditional on parental income, race, and test scores, and estimate fraction lambda of those premia attributable to causal effects by adding rich controls including high-school fixed effects and application-set proxies; baseline assumption lambda = 0.8

Evidence/Result: Regressions controlling for test scores, parent income, race, high-school fixed effects, and application-set proxies imply that at least ~80% of conditional cross-college differences in earnings premia reflect causal effects rather than selection (lambda estimates >= 0.8)

Result: Counterfactual simulations: income-neutral allocations (randomize enrollment conditional on test score, race, and state) reduce segregation substantially overall (close 64% of gap in exposure for low-income students) and narrow parent-income gaps in mobility by ~15% under baseline causal assumption; need-affirmative allocations (give low/middle income students SAT-equivalent preference ~160/128/96/64 points) would essentially eliminate parental income differences across colleges and reduce intergenerational persistence among college students by about 25% under baseline assumption

Claim: Because few low-income students achieve very high SAT/ACT scores, income-neutral reallocation has limited ability to raise absolute bottom-quintile shares at the most selective private (Ivy-Plus) colleges but increases middle-class representation notably

Limitation: Simulation results are sensitive to the assumed causal share of college effects (if differences are pure selection, reallocations would have no mobility impact); simulations also assume colleges' causal effects are invariant to large changes in student composition and do not model general equilibrium or funding shifts

Conclusion: Feasible changes to how students are allocated to colleges could substantially reduce segregation and increase intergenerational mobility even without changing colleges' educational programs, warranting policy attention to application, admissions, and matriculation processes
